         About five miles this side (west) of where I met you is a creek known as the twenty five mile creek, and about a quarter of a mile this side (west) of the creek, the road forks. The left hand, is the traveled road, and about eight or ten miles from the first fork, as above, it forks again.  Either fork goes

to Little River, although the right hand is said [underlined word] to be the shortest and best.   

       I have never traveled the right hand, as I always go to the left [underlined word] and it is an excellent road, but needs a little, (very little however) work to make it first class.  There are two hills upon it, but not bad ones, and can be made good with but little work.
       I enclose you a rough map (my first attempt).  It is of course not well proportioned as to distance &c, but it will, I hope

serve to give you an idea of the road from here to North Fork Town.

    You took the wrong road at Lasley Haines I suppose, which is on Grave creek about 9 miles from here.  I am told that the right hand I spoke of not having ever traveled, comes in there, but am inclined to think it must be further east, (at the next creek likely). Somewhere along there, you took the left [underlined word], when you should have taken the right [word underlined].
       When I got to the fork of

the road, about five miles from where I met you, I saw that you had come down the old road, and was not surprised at your thinking it rough.        Another advantage is that there are no large streams, and travelers are scarcely ever delayed beyond a few hours by high water.

The Post is situated in a sandy, crescent shaped

and alkaline and is not adapted to agriculture.
All that part of the reservation lying

shown on the map is arable but has

the only ferry on the river now known

miles north.  The seasons are dry.  the
